title-group.article-title: Apply with Caution: Introducing UK-Style In-Work Support in Germany

abstract.p: Estimates of the labour supply effects of recent UK reforms in the area of direct taxes and benefits show that policy can have significant influence on the level of employment. We confirm this in a simulation of an in-work support system introduced into the German tax and benefit system. Our simulation results suggest that introducing in-work tax credits in Germany would increase the employment of single individuals by over 105,000 but would result in a reduction of labour supply among individuals living in couples by about 70,000, among both women and men. The result found for men is especially important as it is markedly different from all results for the UK, where the net response among men has always been found to be positive. Our estimation results call for a high degree of caution as far as 'importing' UK-style tax credits to Germany is concerned. In-work support based on family income would reinforce the existing work disincentives for secondary earners, reducing the employment levels of both men and women living in couples.

p.mixed-citation: Submitted February 2006.

Steiner and Wrohlich (2004) discuss in detail positive and negative work incentives for first and secondary earners in married couples induced by joint taxation in Germany. They find that the employment rate of secondary earners in Germany would markedly increase following a move from joint to individual taxation.

In this paper, 'in-work support' refers to government transfers that are conditional on employment. In Germany, people can receive government transfers while working, but there are no transfers that are strictly conditional on being employed (the only minor exception to this is the so-called child supplement (.Kinderzuschlag); see Section IV. 1).

The comparison of labour markets focuses on employment rates rather than on unemployment or labour force participation rates, which are the two most obvious alternative measures, to limit the effect of the definitional and institutional differences between Britain and Germany concerning the unemployed. Employment levels found in the data used here are consistent with OECD statistics on employment for the two countries (see OECD (2005a)).
A description of GSOEP can be downloaded from www.diw.de/soep; see also Haisken-DeNew and Frick (2005).

For Germany, we use the data collected in 2003 as they contain the information about fiscal year 2002. The FRS data are collected to overlap with the government budget calendar, i.e. from April to March. When we refer to a 2002-03 data-set for the FRS, it means that we are considering the data-set for April 2002 to March 2003.

The higher employment rate for women is mainly due to the higher labour market participation of women in east Germany. As documented in previous literature, due to the different histories, the labour market behaviour of women is still quite different between east and west Germany (see, for example, Haan and Steiner (2006)).
For details, see Haan and Myck (2005).

Monetary values used for comparative purposes are expressed in euros using the purchasing power parity (PPP) corrected exchange factor of €/£ = 0.6365 (calculated as the ratio of the UK PPP factor to the German PPP factor from the OECD PPP tables at www.oecd.org/std/ppp). To express weekly values of net incomes and benefits (as is standard practice in the UK) in monthly terms (as is standard in Germany), we multiply weekly values by a factor of 4.35 - the average number of weeks in a month (= 365.25/12/7).

Note that this comparison needs to be interpreted carefully as we focus only on the tax and benefit system but leave out a comparison of important institutions, such as labour market institutions, the education system, childcare, the generosity and quality of public healthcare and other types of public expenditure. Further, for better comparison, we assume in all examples for Germany that individuals are not eligible for the insurance-based unemployment benefit (Arbeitslosengeld) as this is not a permanent transfer. Instead, households receive means-tested social benefits that are the equivalent of the UK's income support.
The same applies to lone-parent families with one child (not shown on Figure 1).

As well as relating to income splitting for one-earner couples, the higher disposable incomes of families with children in Germany relate to receipt of the universal Kindergeld, which in 2002 was €154 for each of the two children per month. The universal child benefit in the UK in 2002 was lower, at €107.65 for the first child and €72.10 for each subsequent child in the family.

Haan and Steiner (2006) provide a detailed description of the reforms and simulate their labour supply and employment effects. They show that the reforms significantly increased labour supply incentives, in particular for households with relatively high income.
This reform is described in detail in Steiner and Wrohlich (2005), and its effects on work incentives have been estimated by, for example, Steiner and Wrohlich (2005) and Bargain et al. (2006).
For more detail, see Steiner (2004).

The UK system also includes a generous childcare credit and additional premiums for families with newborn babies and for working disabled people. These are not modelled in our paper. For more details of the recent UK reforms, see Brewer (2003). More details concerning the design of the UK system in 2005 can be found in Haan and Myck (2005).

As far as generosity of the tax credits is concerned, we have decided to exclude the family premium element of the UK's CTC (see, for example, Haan and Myck (2005)). This is done on the grounds that such extension of child-related support so far up the income distribution in the system with an already high level of universal support (see footnote 11) would be very costly and therefore unlikely to be implemented. Moreover, because of systemic differences in the way childcare is organised in Germany and the UK, and how it is supported through various channels, we do not include childcare subsidies in the tax credits. Such subsidies used to be an element of the WFTC and continue to be a part of the in- work support system in the UK. As mentioned above, average childcare costs are relatively low in Germany compared with the UK. The problem in Germany is the low availability of childcare places, and modelling childcare supply constraints goes beyond the scope of this paper. We think that given these supply constraints and already low childcare costs, such additional childcare subsidies would, in reality, have only a modest effect on employment in Germany.

We assume that working hours can be described by a distribution with six discrete points. We define on hours intervals 0, (0,12), [12,20), [20,34), [34,40] and >40 according to the empirical distribution in the data (GSOEP 2003). The empirical mean of the distribution describes the discrete hours points. For couples, we assume a joint labour supply model and specify 6x6 discrete points. For more details, see Bargain et al. (2006).
For further information with descriptive statistics and a discussion of the main results, see Bargain et al. (2006).

We have estimated the effect of tax credits on couples where one spouse is self-employed, in education or retired, or older than 59. We find that the effects for both men and women are negligible. Simulation results for these groups can be obtained from the authors.
We cannot estimate preferences directly for 2005 as the data for fiscal year 2005 are not yet available.

Labour supply effects induced by the fiscal reforms between 2002 and 2005 are not discussed here. In general, the 2005 system induces higher labour supply incentives, mainly due to the income tax reform. Haan and Steiner (2006) estimate an employment effect of the tax reform of about 150,000 additional participants. Estimated labour supply effects of the Hartz Reform (for example, the Minijob reform) are of negligible size; see Steiner and Wrohlich (2005) or Bargain et al. (2006).

Note that this does not necessarily mean that these would then become two-earner couples since we cannot say much, on the basis of Table 6, about the employment status of the men in this case under the simulated system.
For a summary of results, see Blundell and Reed (2000).
We do not report labour supply effects separately by the age of children here. Results can be obtained from the authors on request.
A system of individual tax credits could replace the Minijob subsidies, which support employment at very low hours of work.
